channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Top Saddam Hussein Aide Reported Killed in Northern Iraq
item.description: The aide, Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, an ally of the Islamic State, was the highest-ranking deputy to Mr. Hussein not caught in the American invasion.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Some Foreign-Owned Shops and Cars Torched in Johannesburg
item.description: Several shops and cars owned by foreigners were torched in downtown Johannesburg overnight in continued anti-immigrant attacks but another city that had seen the worst violence was calm, authorities said Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Germanwings Memorial Service Held at Cologne Cathedral
item.description: The service at the Cologne Cathedral illustrated the extent to which this country has been affected by the plane crash, which killed 150 people.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: President Joachim Gauck of Germany addressed the memorial service in Cologne on Friday for the 150 people killed in the Germanwings plane crash.

item.title: Loose Ends: Foot Fungus Is Better in America
item.description: Why do German pharmacies have to be so humiliating?
item.dc:creator: FIROOZEH DUMAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tiananmen Protester’s Plea to China: Let Me See My Dying Mother
item.description: Chinese consular officials have so far ignored Xiong Yan’s request, he said, reflecting how the country has yet to come to terms with the pro-democracy demonstrations 26 years ago.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Xiong Yan, center, one of the leaders of the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, at a march in Hong Kong in 2009 marking the 20th anniversary of the protests and their suppression by the military.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Ban on Beef in India Is Not the Answer
item.description: Imposing ideals from a mythic past will only alienate minorities.
item.dc:creator: MANIL SURI

item.title: Italian Navy Takes Control of Fishing Boat Seized Near Libya
item.description: The vessel and its crew had been taken by armed men 90 miles off Libya’s coast, in international waters, the Sicilian fishing cooperative that the boat belonged to said.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: South Africa Seeks Diplomatic Support to Defeat Anti-Immigrant Unrest
item.description: South Africa sought diplomatic support from countries across the continent on Friday to defeat the "demon" of anti-immigrant violence in which at least four people have been killed over the past fortnight.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Opinion: Armenians Shouldn’t Let Genocide Define Us
item.description: We must recognize that the horror of 1915 isn't the sum of our identity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MELINE TOUMANI
item.media:credit: Scout Tufankjian/Polaris, from, There Is Only the Earth (Melcher Media)
item.media:description: A young Armenian traditional dancer waits to perform during a show to celebrate Armenia's First Republic Day at Yerevan's Opera House.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Reining in Soldiers of Fortune
item.description: Mercenaries are here to stay, and the best way to control them is through the marketplace.
item.dc:creator: SEAN MCFATE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Willis Barnstone on Translating Mao and Touring Beijing With Allen Ginsberg
item.description: The poet Willis Barnstone talks about his long flirtation with China and the time Allen Ginsberg visited him there.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: U.N. Calls on Western Nations to Shelter Syrian Refugees
item.description: Not since the wave of people who fled after the war in Vietnam have the world’s industrialized countries been under such intense pressure to share the burden of taking in refugees, experts say.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on their way to start the registration process after crossing into Jordan, at Zaatari Camp in 2013.

item.title: Chinese Journalist Sentenced to 7 Years on Charges of Leaking State Secrets
item.description: Gao Yu, a 71-year-old who has repeatedly challenged the Communist Party during a decades-long career, indicated she would appeal.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Gao Yu, 71, indicated she would appeal.

item.title: Chinese Journalist Sentenced to 7 Years on Charges of Leaking State Secrets
item.description: Gao Yu, a 71-year-old who has repeatedly challenged the Communist Party during a decades-long career, indicated she would appeal.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Gao Yu, 71, indicated she would appeal.

item.title: Voting Ends in Sudan With a Small Turnout
item.description: President Omar al-Bashir, in power more than 25 years, is expected to win amid widespread apathy and a call for a boycott by opposition groups.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Gunmen Kill Pro-Russian Journalist in Kiev
item.description: The journalist, Oles Buzina, 45, publicly opposed the protests that led to the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanukovych in 2014.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Mexico’s President Rolls Out Plan to Save Endangered Porpoise
item.description: The Mexican Navy will expand patrols to stop the illegal fishing that threatens the vaquita, and gillnets that accidentally snare and kill them will be banned for two years.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: N.Y.U. Labor Guidelines Failed to Protect 10,000 Workers in Abu Dhabi, Report Says
item.description: The report, by an international investigative firm, said some subcontractors employed at the university’s Abu Dhabi campus were exempted from N.Y.U. guidelines based on decisions by local contractors.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE SAUL
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction workers at the site of N.Y.U.’s campus in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, last April. Many workers at the campus were recruited from South Asia.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pushing Back Against the Authorities in China ‘According to the Law’
item.description: Supporters are demanding the Chinese government compensate and apologize to feminists for detaining them, and one group says it will engage a lawyer to defend its reputation against official criticism of involvement in the high-profile case.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The released feminists, from left: Li Tinging, Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan and Wu Rongrong, whose supporters are now lobbying for them to receive compensation and a public apology.

item.title: Trial of Karma al-Khayat, Lebanese Journalist, Begins in Hague Tribunal
item.description: The journalist faces charges for publishing confidential information from an investigation into the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
